comments.commentBody: Get ready for another nineteen months of candidates on both sides explaining in only the simplest, most carefully chosen, most headline-worthy phrases why they want to be president, and where they want to take the country.  If it's substance you want, even the barest substance, another country whose electorate actually thinks might be more your speed.
I think you were looking at the right character if you go by the books, but if you watched who was squirming the most, it is likely Tormund in the tv show.
I had the same question! Mance on fire in the books behaves differently than Mance on fire on TV, so I'm not sure whether looking at Rattleshirt means anything or not.

We've been warned that this is the season where the shows veer away from the books. Don't use the books as your source of truth for the TV series any longer. Ciarin Hinds believes he is done with the show, so don't expect Mance to survive in this version.

SPOILER comment:

So... is Mance really actually dead in the tv series? Cause he's not in the books, and I am super confused on what to expect and think right now. The whole time that scene was happening, I was watching Rattleshirt right next to Tormond Giantsbane. But now I'm not so sure. ARGH!

@Larry: How would you escape from someone who's driving at 150 MPH and who doesn't slow down for pedestrians?  The French Connection was a great movie in part because it sized up the pathology of someone who would do such a thing even if the person he's pursuing is a big-time narcotics dealer.  I'd be okay with these movies if they were, in fact, being projected as fantasies taking place a long long time ago in a galaxy far far away.  But that's not what the filmmakers are doing here.
Wouldn't the arc of Paul Walkers' life (star of Fast and Furious) be enough of a warning?

Again, are you expecting realism in EVERY movie? And yes, driving 151 MPH would do the trick.

And your citation of the French Connection shows how off-base you are, as that car chase (see the doc. on YouTube) was pieced together, etc. and is not realistic either.

If people actually drove the way the characters in these movies do they'd all be dead within 30 seconds, and they'd take a lot of innocent pedestrians and motorists along with them.  And yet we're supposed to cheer them on as "action heroes."  Drivers with a "need for speed" should stick to Nascar, and so should their fans.  This kind of cinematic spectacle isn't as harmless as people would like to believe.

Bill,
Sitting comfortably in BC you're making some pretty wild accusations about America. Your diatribe would carry more weight if it was supported by facts; " ...in a racist, authoritarian country owned and run by a criminal class"...really?
utter nonsense, this guy is a rogue cop, it says nothing whatever about policing or racism in a larger sense.  And just who is this "criminal class" that is training cops to kill?

That song is about taking a good kid and training him for Vietnam. Maybe you ought to brush up on Walter Scott's many run ins with the law and criminal behavior. He actually isn't a good kid or person.

"They took a clean-cut kid
and made a killer out of him/
That's what they did . . ."
-- Bob Dylan

Story of the USA. It isn't Slagger's mother or father, and it isn't Slagerr's past. It's the institution of policing in the USA. This shooting is what it means to be an instrument of state violence in a racist, authoritarian country owned and run by a criminal class that hires and trains ordinary people to be killers.
And frankly too skinny, yes? No matter how much they pad him?

Impossible to unhear Welles' reading of Bolt's line about Henry--be very careful about what you put into that head, because you will NEVER get it out again.  All of Welles' years in Hollywood, dealing with producers and vice-presidents, are in his voice.

Not only Leo McKern but Orson Welles.  Jonathan Pryce is a great actor but Welles gave us a sense that Wolsey was just as manipulative as everybody else who was angling for power.  Pryce comes across as too amiable a guy to have ended up with so much power before he came crashing down.

I thought they did a poor job with the masque.  I say the series before I saw the play and in the play it made me jump in my seat the way they roles that out - much more violent and nasty than it was on screen - or maybe I just couldn't see it well on tv?
Don't forget Thomas Boleyn. The author made humorous note of the multiplicity of Thomases   in the novel

the auto correct on here is killing me.

my post should read " I saW the series before I saw the play and in the play it made me jump in my seat the way they rolled that out - much more violent and nasty than it was on screen - or maybe I just couldn't see it well on tv?"

I find myself rooting for Thomas. I noticed that he took note of the revelers who had taken down the mock-Wolsey after the Cardinal's demise, and I suspect that he will take them down, one by one, out of loyalty for his late friend and mentor, the one man who had never done him any harm.
Arya is in the next episode. Brandon will not be featured this season (most likely because the show has caught up with the books).

It does seem like Dany will have to pay for this. The scene from last season showing her collaring/chaining the dragons was pretty powerful. The fact that she essentially enslaves that from which she derives her power also runs contrary to pretty much everything her character is supposed to stand for.

Not sure what her options are, though. My previous reactions to seeing the dragons for the first time in a season was usually a simple "cool," or "wow." This time it was more like holy crap, get away from that thing!
George RR Martin has stated (not in the books - it's not a spoiler) that Daenerys does NOT have a special immunity from fire - the birth of the dragons was a one-time event.
Perhaps to keep them in hiding from everyone else???  What if one of the dragons got loose?

To answer one of your questions, Jeremy, yes, there was sufficient action for me. Luckily I had watched the last three episodes of last season to remind me of where everybody was.

Of course, I'm sure we all have our favorites (for me: Tyrion and Daenerys and, hopefully sometime soon, Tyrion-and-Daenerys and dragons!) and un-favorites (the Stannis clan could drop down the moon well for all I care), so the show had to touch base with them all to keep everyone happy. Worked for me!

One thing that bugged me again while re-watching the episodes: why did Daenerys have to shut the dragons up in the dark, anyway? They were chained up; leave the door cracked, for the love of Pete! No wonder they were so grouchy...serve her right if they bit her. And her so nice to slaves and everybody, but not her beloved dragons? Shame!

Okay, I forgive her!

Now to wait a *whole week* for more =whine= ...

Phillip would be happy to be "out of work." Elizabeth, not so much, but she'd adjust. Anyway, don't you eventually get too old or burned out to keep up all the "love affairs" and derring do they're involved in each week?
And frankly too skinny, yes? No matter how much they pad him?
So did my parents, Richard. That was one of many scenes that did not ring true.

Off the course perhaps. On the the course, no way. Jordan shows his emotions - whether it be disappointment when things go wrong or when he talks to the ball in flight, sometimes in unpleasant tones.

Not so with Roger. Unflappable on the court. There is no one like Roger.
Well, and a gentlewoman's.

@Victor

So true. I used to think a lot of Tiger. Not so much anymore. And I think his on-course performance since the cratering of his personal life are linked. Call me crazy.

Roger Federer, as you point out, is a gentleman. Travels with his family. No scandals. Seems to work for some.

I am rooting for Jordan to stay as grounded as he now appears to be. Like Clayton Kershaw, there are still genuine and rooted people out there. The press will take brief note of it and move on. But I agree with your hope.
This guy reminds me of a young Roger Federer, all class and humility. None of the arrogance and bravado of Tiger. This kid will make golf a gentleman's sport again.

My father never discussed his wishes until he was diagnosed with terminal brain cancer. He carefully listened to what the medical staff told him, then refused active treatment. My mother accepted his choice. When she left the room, a doctor pulled her aside and said she was "murdering her husband" because she didn't try to talk him into interventions that might have given him a couple of extra months.

The upshot is, whatever people feel on life-and-death issues, they feel strongly. Dr. Lerner's actions were based on knowledge and love for his father, but there are people who won't accept that.
You are showing incredible American bias. McIlroy won two majors last year. Let's see what Speith does
That's your problem if you think Tiger is bigger than golf itself.

Big Al you are not a true lover of the game if all you care about is Tiger....good riddance to him, Spieth is a breath of fresh air. There are other golfers besides Woods thankfully and are more enjoyable to watch. Tired of Woods' tantrums and excuses.

Nice to see this young man have his fifteen minutes of fame. As a true golf aficionado, however, I have to say that all of us were more interested in Tiger's rounds than in Jordan's twenty-first birthday gift. If Tiger continues to improve, we'll watch TV golf. If not, sayonara to it; instead, we'll read a good book or take a walk.

Tiger has become nothing but goldbricker with all his excuses and complaints  about this health, bones pooping out, back problems  sprains  and the rest.  He is just burned out and will soon become history.
Hey, McIlroy is only 25 and has won 4 majors. Not bad going. You're setting the bar a bit high.

Ever since the decline of Tiger, every new winner of a major title has been proclaimed the next biggest thing. They have all failed to pan out. The closest to being the real deal is Rory McIlroy, but as we saw this weekend, golf is a brutal sports. It takes truly exceptional golfers to dominate the sports.

While I do not doubt that Jordan is a great player and a great person I will wait for a few years before I agree he is the next greatest thing. Every week he is going to be going up against the best of the best, and some weeks you are just not going to have it.

That said, for the past couple of years Jordan has displayed all the signs of greatness. I am just worried that that his anointment as the next big thing will make people grumble every time he fails to win. Rory can tell him all about that.

@ Winemaster
Before spewing nonsense about Augusta National still being a white man only club, you obviously have not paid attention that that changed already in 2012 when Condoleezza Rice, who is both black and a woman, and Darla Moore became members.
In 2014 Ginni Rometty became the third woman member.

Augusta National is all about history. If the Club was not in the media spotlight, slaves would be serving the meals and cleaning up after the tournament ends. Grudgingly adding just two female members is not exactly positive change.

@ gcarey;
In 2014 another female member, Ginni Rometty, was invited into the club in addition to Condoleezza Rice and Darla Moore.

No body could ever begrudge this young man at age  21, He deserve all the glory for the remarkable show of poise, talent and decency. But I am not sure tat it can also be said of the  others like minded  white men only members of Augusta National hierarchy. Where there are no women or even men of other races.

Then, LaocOO, support high school and college golf teams from historically Black high schools, colleges and universities. Put your love, support and money where your rhetoric is. We will then develop and discover more Tigers of both genders.

They are all out there, waiting for your support. What are you waiting for? LadocOO?

“Moral indignation is jealousy with a halo.” --HG Wells

Oh, and well done, Mr. Spieth.

Looks like animal abuse to me.
Birds would not be able to move normally without feathers.

I imagine that Noah's parents talked about the brother "over" him when they thought he was too young to understand.

As a teacher of young children for 35 years, as well as a parent, I have come to learn that kids are never too young to pick up on cues from the significant adults in their lives, even if they don't understand exactly. It's likely that some small snippet of information lodged itself in his mind without much context, so he added his own to make sense of the small bit(s) he had.

I really like the way Rylance plays Cromwell. You can read what he's thinking in his face. You can certainly see the wheels constantly turning in his mind.
He's a sympathetic figure right now and you want him to succeed. I wonder how long will he stay that way? You can't rise to the position of power that Cromwell did and still be nice guy'. He didn't go to Wolsey when he needed him most and he excused it by saying he had to remain where he was to 'take care of things' near the court. Next week should show how his character is going to develop.
Anything a national government can do today on the Internet will be within the capabilities of criminal hackers in a year or two.  We'd best start securing everything now...

This was fantastic. Not sure what the correct amount of dressing one should hold over before adding ketchup and Worcestershire, but 1/4 cup tasted too much like ketchup, while 1/2 cup seemed to be the right proportion, but too much for the salad. That being said this salad was impressive!
Not the densest or thickest of lasagnas, but fantastic. Homemade pasta at the second to lowest setting was terrific instead of store-bought No-Boil pasta. It does taste rich, but is very light.

The media keep saying that Hillary has to explain why she wants to be president and calling it a "central question". Give me a break. That's not a central question, it's a stupid question. Any answer is going to sound pretentious.

The central question for ALL the candidates is what will you fight for and prioritize to achieve as President?

The media seems to single out Hillary to harass while the clowns on the Republican side get away with ignorance and no rationale whatsoever.

It seems like the kind of situation where the smart kid in school is pressured with high expectations and the dumb kids are allowed to get away with shenanigans because of low expectations.

I am not amused by the Republican class clowns because I know there is too much at risk if one of them gets into the White House....
